docs.lead_paragraph: At schools across the land, students are engaged in that most secular December ritual: sweating midterm exams. And in a new study of math testing, psychologists are reporting that intense exam pressure is actually more likely to impair the performance of very good students than mediocre ones. Rushed, worried about pleasing others, these students can lose their most valuable intellectual asset: short-term or working memory, the ability to keep numbers and thoughts in a kind of holding pattern while focusing on the problem at hand. Motivated students whose working memories are less powerful are less likely to fold under exam pressure, the study found.

headline.main: When Pressure Is On, Good Students Suffer
